The American Legacy Foundation in Washington said yesterday that it had named three executives to new posts as part of a reorganization that comes after the departure of Charles A. Wolfe, 38, chief operating officer. The foundation is financed by the recent $206 billion settlement reached by 46 state attorneys general and the tobacco industry.

Mitch Zeller, 42, was named executive vice president; he had been director for the office of tobacco programs at the Food and Drug Administration in Rockville, Md. Lyndon Haviland, 37, vice president for program development, was named executive vice president for program development and research. And Anthony O'Toole, 49, was named executive vice president and chief financial officer; he had been associate vice president for financial services and systems at the Health Sciences Division of Columbia University in New York.
Mr. Wolfe supervised the selection of an agency consortium that is creating a campaign, carrying the theme ''Truth,'' meant to reduce smoking among teenagers and young adults.
